choices.C: Create a Separate partition of several hundred megabytes and place the swap file there
choices.A: Use VMware to be able to capture the data in memory and examine it
choices.D: Use intrusion forensic techniques to study memory resident infections
choices.B: Give the Operating System a minimal amount of memory, forcing it to use a swap file

questions.question_text: Volatile Memory is one of the leading problems for forensics. Worms such as code Red are memory resident and do write themselves to the hard drive, if you turn the system off they disappear. In a lab environment, which of the following options would you suggest as the most appropriate to overcome the problem of capturing volatile memory?

discussion.content:
A. Use VMware to be able to capture the data in memory and examine it

Using virtualization software like VMware allows you to take snapshots of the entire system state, including the contents of volatile memory. This snapshot can be analyzed later to investigate memory-resident malware without the risk of losing data when the system is powered off. Virtualization provides a controlled environment where you can capture and analyze volatile memory effectively.

Selected Answer: A
A memory snapshot in VMWare is way easier then just placing swap on a separate partition.

Don't get mixed up between ports 25 and 110. Both are mail ports but you would use 25 in this case.
Port 10 and 135 have nothing to do with email.
See:
https://opensource.com/article/18/10/common-network-ports
and 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_TCP_and_UDP_port_numbers

questions.question_text: You are working in the security Department of law firm. One of the attorneys asks you about the topic of sending fake email because he has a client who has been charged with doing just that. His client alleges that he is innocent and that there is no way for a fake email to actually be sent. You inform the attorney that his client is mistaken and that fake email is possibility and that you can prove it. You return to your desk and craft a fake email to the attorney that appears to come from his boss. What port do you send the email to on the company SMTP server?

choices.A: Refer the reporter to the attorney that retained you
choices.D: Answer only the questions that help your case
choices.C: Answer all the reporter's questions as completely as possible

discussion.content:
"no comment" can sometimes be perceived as evasive or uncooperative therefore referring the reporter to the attorney shows that you are cooperating within the boundaries of legal and ethical guidelines.

Answer: A

'A' is correct, but this would also raise some flags, if you have nothing to hide, why would you refer to your attorney. This is a typical Ec-Counsil question and up to their discretion to choose what is right and wrong.

comments.content: You must respect maximun reserve about cases you are working/ worked on. Thats the why you cannot say anything about, even if you have nothing to hide: Its not you, friend... Its your customer. And your customer is the attorney who hired you.

discussion.content: "No Comment" could attract more attention. You should refer them to the attorney.

questions.question_text: What should you do when approached by a reporter about a case that you are working on or have worked on?

discussion.content: You are correct, but of the 4 answers, slack space is still the best, we know its not a sector, MFR or Meta Data.
question doesn't make any sense. Slack space is empty space it does not contain data.

comments.content: "Slack space is empty space it does not contain data." <-- Strongly dissagree with that. Have a look --> https://computersecuritystudent.com/FORENSICS/HIDING/lesson1/index.html

questions.question_text: Which of the following refers to the data that might still exist in a cluster even though the original file has been overwritten by another file?

choices.D: Secure the evidence; prepare the system for acquisition; Connect the target media; copy the media
choices.B: Prepare the system for acquisition; Connect the target media; copy the media; Secure the evidence
choices.C: Connect the target media; Prepare the system for acquisition; Secure the evidence; Copy the media
choices.A: Connect the target media; prepare the system for acquisition; Secure the evidence; Copy the media

discussion.content: Going with B as well. Due to the fact you always end with securing the evidence. Copying would NOT be the last thing done. Hence it takes out all of the other answers

questions.question_text: Chris has been called upon to investigate a hacking incident reported by one of his clients. The company suspects the involvement of an insider accomplice in the attack. Upon reaching the incident scene, Chris secures the physical area, records the scene using visual media. He shuts the system down by pulling the power plug so that he does not disturb the system in any way. He labels all cables and connectors prior to disconnecting any. What do you think would be the next sequence of events?
